title: The Data Center is the New Unit of Compute: Crusoe CEO Chase Lochmiller

rawLines.text: very happy to welcome Chase Lockach
Miller and my partner David Khan. And
Chase is somebody um who I've gotten to
meet a couple times over the years. And
the two things that have stuck out to me
and and why I'm excited to have him
here. One, guy's brilliant. Good
starting point. two, he has a really
interesting and different point of view
on this market than most of the people
in this room because it's anchored more
around servers, steel, power, the raw
infrastructure even beneath the GPU
level that is powering this whole
revolution. And our partner David is the
perfect person to interview him because
for better or for worse, David's simple
observation that there's a heck of a lot
of money going into the ground and not a
lot of application revenue coming back
to pay it off yet made him famous andor
notorious for AI's $600 billion
question. So I will hand it off to David
and Chase. Thank you. Thanks Pat. So I'm
excited to introduce this session. We're
going to talk about the AI industrial
revolution underlining the word
industrial. Uh we're going to talk about
steel servers and power. Jensen already
talked to us about servers. So we're
going to focus on steel and power. I
think everybody here knows that there's
a race going on between the most
powerful companies in the world to build
the biggest GPU clusters. We heard about
100,000 GPU clusters. We're now hearing
about 300,000 GPU clusters and big tech
companies are talking about million GPU
clusters. And the person at the center
of all of that is Chase. And so I'm
excited to interview him and we're going
to talk about what's going on behind
that. Uh Chase, right now you have I
think 5,000 people in Abalene, Texas
building a data center. We do. Yeah.
5,000 people every day uh on site uh
kind of working around the clock to you
know accelerate uh accelerate AI
infrastructure. Maybe talk to us a
little bit about we think about we we
understand Jensen servers. We know that
they go in a data center. Maybe some
people here can visualize a data center
or have been to a data center. But what
does it take to start from land
basically and build one of these AI
factories?
Yeah, I I think I think it's important
to like one take a step back and just
evaluate like what is the AI factory?
What is the AI data center of the future
and how does it differ from existing
data centers? because um you know like a
data center as a you know it's a bit of
an overloaded term to be honest like
calling you know a data center from 20
years ago that's serving you know a web
page uh the same thing as you know a
high performance AI data center of today
that's you know managing a you know
100,000 plus GPU cluster it's like you
know calling a go-kart and like a you
know uh Range Rover like both vehicles
right they're both yeah they are both
vehicles but like you probably wouldn't
use them for the same things Right. Um
so uh you know I I think uh I I think
when you look at today's data center
infrastructure and what what's really
required to scale AI um it is a very
industrial process right the amount of
energy that goes into it um you know I
know it's been talked about quite a bit
but I think helping put it in context
like you know I think Northern Virginia
many people would consider to be like
the center of the world for data centers
right that's like where most of the
internet happens. Um, you know, we've
been building it for decades, right? So,
what's like the capacity of Northern
Virginia? It's about, you know, JL
published a report end of 24. It was
like roughly 4 and a.5 gawatts of total
capacity in Northern Virginia. Like,
Cruso is a 7-year-old startup. Uh, you
know, we're building big AI
infrastructure. We're currently working
on about 2 gigawatts of, you know,
capacity currently under construction.
We about 20 gigawatts in the pipeline.
So you're talking about like you know it
it's just completely transforming the
both the energy landscape and the data
center landscape uh to make AI a reality
uh because of the amount of
infrastructure required to build it. Now
like the bottlenecks of it you know
they're constantly moving around right I
mean I think there was a period of time
where it was impossible to get chips uh
you know and and that was the major
bottleneck. I think a lot of that is you
know uh eased up um as you know
production both at TSMC and Nvidia have
sort of uh increased to you know make
make chips more available um but you
know power steel data center space that
that has become a major bottleneck and
these are complex supply chains that you
know are not easy to accelerate so you
know Cruso's always kind of taken this
very first principled vertically
integrated approach to things and so you
know just to give you an example we've
stood up a lot of manufacturing
ourselves domestically here in the US to
help accelerate operate time timelines
like speed is a critical advantage for
us. Um so you know we've got quotes for
you know low voltage switch gear right
so it's basically like uh you know where
all you know it's sort of the electrical
control room for the data center um and
the quotes we were getting were 100
weeks I was like that's insane you know
100 weeks I don't have I don't have 100
weeks so we stood up a factory and we
started making switch gear ourselves now
we make it in 22 weeks um and just like
finding elements in the supply chain
where you know we could really help
accelerate um a lot of this
infrastructure has been critical to our
success
uh in in sort of building these very
large scale projects, you know, faster
than anybody's ever done it before. How
have you convinced big tech companies to
work with you? When I think about
Amazon, Google, Microsoft, I mean, these
companies are data center companies. And
for the last wave, the cloud wave, this
was an internal core competency for
these companies, right? They all built
their own data centers. They have
massive teams doing that. And yet you
guys, this startup that seven years ago
was building little containers on top of
flare gassing is now a partner to a lot
of these companies to build their data
centers. How do you make that argument?
Well, I think I think it's worth
appreciating that um while big tech is
good at a lot of things, they're not
inherently designed to move quickly. In
fact, like structurally, they're
designed to not move quickly, especially
when there's like very big purchasing
decisions. So, um, just like the
approval process of like, you know, when
when I need to make a decision to buy
something, it's like it's like I just
make the decision and then it like
happens that day. Um, and and you know,
if you look at like Microsoft, there's
like 19 layers of approval that sort of
go into all these processes. So, like
you know, just from the starting line,
there's like a massive disadvantage for
them to move quickly. Now they've all
developed great programs and they're
looking at this like you know a big data
center you know 100 megawatt plus uh
would you know 3 to 5year type programs
um you know our first phase of what
we're doing in Abene we're hitting 300
days um our second phase we're actually
just over 200 days so we're like
massively accelerating the time to
market of this infrastructure which is
the major value prop to big tech
companies and big AI labs that are
interested in this type type of scale
and uh you know purpose build
infrastructure. There are rumors that
you guys are involved in Stargate. I
don't know if you're allowed to comment
on that, but what do you think about
these mega scale data centers, not just
at the level of big tech, but also
nation states, right? Something Jensen
talked about and talks about on his
earnings calls is sovereign data centers
and sovereign AI strategy. As we go from
data centers in Northern Virginia that
you and I can go visit to these massive
projects, what does it look like? What
is the real estate footprint? How should
governments think about it? How do you
see that evolving? Yeah, I think uh
there's there's two big verticals that
are driving this. One is that um you
know because of the scale of energy
needed um for this infrastructure at
scale like you know you really do need
to take an energy first approach and
that's really what Crusoe's done like
bringing the demand for computing
infrastructure to areas where we can
access lowcost clean and abundant
energy. That's really what brought us to
West Texas. That's what brought us to
Abalene, Texas, was that uh there was a
massive overbuild of of renewables, uh
particularly wind, um where people were
getting negatively priced power on the
wind power they were generating and
selling, something like 30% of the time.
And there was actually uh an abundance
of curtailment. Uh which means they
could be producing power, but they
actually just don't because they don't
want to sell it at a negative price. And
so, you know, that's sort of the
opposite problem that AI has. AI like
needs a lot of energy. So it was kind of
a natural fit to say, well, nobody's
ever built a data center in Abalene,
Texas, but if we did that, we would have
this abundant clean energy to power it.
Um, so that's really what drove us to be
there. I think, you know, the sovereign
AI common, I think, is is a pretty
interesting one. Uh, because that's the
other dimension that we're seeing a lot
of uh geographic uh dispersion um in the
demand for this type of infrastructure.
And that really has to do with like data
locality. when people think about uh you
know there's there's data that you know
maybe owned by a nation state or you
know can't leave the uh you know four
walls of the kingdom like you know it
has to live there um and they want to do
something very special with that so um
that that's really catalyzed a lot of
demand for investment um in in domestic
AI strategies and I think people are
looking at that this from like you know
geopolitical uh you know power shifts as
well. maybe talk to us a bit more about
energy. Um, you know, I think probably
everyone in the audience has some
abstract notion that energy is going to
be the constraint in AI and Sonia sent
me this chart last week of US energy is
like this and China energy is like this.
And so as you talk about the
geopolitical components, it really
matters. Maybe break down for us the
energy problem. Where is there really a
constraint? Where is there not a
constraint? How are we going to
accelerate generation? What does the
energy picture look like? And and and
how bad is the situation right now?
Yeah, I I think it's uh it's an
interesting problem because when you
look at the US, like the utilities have
been such a sleepy industry for such a
long period of time. Like our total
generation capacity hasn't really grown
that much. It's kind of like flatlined
uh as things have gotten more efficient
as you know uh uh uh as you know e even
with electrification trends like just
efficiencies have sort of outpaced
demand growth. Um and then AI is like
this step function change in demand,
right? So, um, you're sort of seeing
these like sleeping giants being woken
up being like, "Hey, I need a gigawatt
of power. Like, where's that going to
come from?" Um, you know, we've sort of
again sort of had to take this very
first principled approach of like, okay,
well, if we can't get the power from the
utility, could we build a power plant?
Um, so, you know, we we've done things
like that. Um, you know, we we view AI
as this massive opportunity to actually
accelerate um next generation energy
technologies as well. Um I have three
different deals with uh small modular
reactor companies that you know
hopefully will accelerate uh uh nuclear
as a as a critical uh piece of the
energy to power uh the data centers of
the future. Um so you know I I I kind of
view this as a massive opportunity for
the industry to accelerate a lot of
interesting energy technologies. Um and
uh you know bring us forward into uh a
future where both intelligence and
energy are both widely abundant. Um and
I think that's really what's special
about this moment in time is that you
know for the first time in human history
we're really able to manufacture
intelligence. Right? previous to this
like you know that you had to do it the
organic way which is you know just
having kids uh so uh you know and it
takes long to you know grow them right
and until they're actually productive
intelligent beings you know today you
know we can we can manufacture
intelligence with silicon and uh you
know that I and I think that's really
what's special about um kind of this
boom that's taking place and you know
these AI factories are complex right I
mean Jensen's you know all of the things
that he spoke about earlier
uh in terms of the networking you know
fabric and you know MVLink and
Infiniband and you know uh building
these large scale coherent clusters um
is a is a is a massive technological
breakthrough in terms of making that uh
manufactured intelligence reality but
there's all the different components
around it that you know Cruso is really
focused on building between the data
center um and then high performance
services virtualization uh you know
around uh around the compute
infrastructure. Can you take us behind
the scenes a bit on the energy
negotiation? And it's something that I
sort of imagine. There's not that many
people. You understand the utility
world. I think most of us probably
don't. Um I've when I talk about you at
Sequo, I've often talked about you as
like you're the Rockefeller of this
industry, right? Like you're going out
there and you're negotiating with the
power the power guy and you're
negotiating these deals and somebody has
to do that and that enables everything
else on top of it. How does that
actually happen?
Um well, you know, number one, I have a
great team. Uh I have great people that
are really focused on this and and we've
pulled we've had to pull people from
very uh diverse you know backgrounds. So
you know uh I actually have a guy on my
team that uh I don't know if anybody's a
a fan of the show Land Man, but you know
a guy on my team actually used to be a
landman. Um and so you know he was
previously negotiating with farmers and
uh ranchers just around uh uh mineral
rights you know basically around the
subsurface of what they were doing. uh
you know now he's negotiating you know
largecale energy deals you know and and
and land and power deals uh to sort of
make uh these large scale AI factories a
reality you know uh there's a lot of
like noise that's sort of been created
like a lot of inbound requests like you
know people are sending our team stuff I
can't even imagine what you know Sam is
getting bombarded with in terms of
opportunities um but it's it's a lot
more than just like having power to make
a big AI factory happen and we've seen
kind of like the two guys in a pickup
truck uh saying like, "Oh yeah, my
cousin's got this big power line that
runs through his property and I got a
bunch of, you know, I got this ranch in
Texas. Like, you know, can we build a
big AI data center there?" And, you
know, typically the answer is no. Um uh
but, you know, it's it's uh there
there's a confluence of a lot of
different components that have to come
together between uh power, networking,
permitting uh to to to and and then, you
know, the whole supply chain to to
really make this happen. Um, you know,
to put it in perspective, in Abalene,
Texas, you know, we have 5,000 people,
you know, working there. Uh, the town of
Abene's 120,000 people, right? So, um,
you're talking about employing a very
substantial part of the town and and and
frankly having to import a lot of labor,
um, because, you know, these are very
skilled trades between electrical,
mechanical, um, and and various
construction trades that, uh, you know,
sort of make make this, uh, build a
reality. Will you talk to us a little
bit about data center design? You can
read I mean Meta publishes online. All
the big tech companies publish online.
You can really go through in detail what
is the plan, how does the data center
look. One thing that always resonated
with me is your old school data center
in Virginia. You have these servers
spread out uh over the entire data
center and now you have these big data
centers that are repurposed and all the
GPUs are in like one little cluster,
right? Because of the way that you need
to design the data center. The
networking is changing and Jensen has
been pushing this forward. What does the
data center of the future look like? How
does liquid cooling fit in? How should
we think about what a future data center
even is? Yeah, I I mean honestly this is
really what got me into this in the
first place was that you know Crusoe was
building an AI cloud platform and I was
looking at sort of the road maps and the
changing compute architectures and I
said to myself like you know as you know
as I look forward at these changing
comput architectures the data center in
order to support these things is
fundamentally going to have to shift. So
in order to build the best AI cloud
platform in the world, I really need to
be the best at building AI data centers.
Um and uh you know the the overall I I
think the the biggest aspect is really
you know the overall power density that
you're seeing. So if you look 20 years
ago a traditional data center rack might
have been 2 kilowatts maybe 4 kilowatts.
Um you know the NVL72 the GB200 racks
are about 120 to 130 kilowatts. um you
know what Jensen just announced at GTC
was the uh the the Vera Rubin Ultra
which will be a 600 kilowatt rack
installation. So you're talking about
you know multiple orders of magnitude
increase in overall power density that
fundamentally changes like you know the
thermodynamics like involved in in the
actual data center. So you have to you
have to change sort of the cooling
architectures quite a bit. So when you
go into one of our data centers it kind
of it's it's pretty interesting. It
looks like the water works right.
There's massive pipes uh that are moving
water throughout the throughout the data
center. Um you know each building has
about a million gallons of water. Um
that sort of you know feeds cold water
into you know the racks to to cool the
chip with a direct to direct to chip
look at cooled architecture. Um then it
feeds out to a uh a chiller that that
basically exhausts the heat um you know
in the outside. So um there's 84
chillers per building. Um and then you
know we're very focused on uh what would
the network look like around that data
center because again we're not thinking
about this at the chip layer or the
server layer. We're really thinking
about this at the cluster layer, right?
The data center is the new unit of
compute and you know that's really what
the AI factory is is the data center
scale computer. Um and when we think
about that we also think about like what
about connecting multiple buildings
together. So you know in Abene we have
we have eight separate buildings that
are under construction on that site. um
all planned to be interconnected.
There's 44inch conduits that connect
each network core to one another um so
that you can have one coherent cluster
um of GB200s, you know, and uh that'll
be the biggest in the world at that, you
know, once it's once it's live. So, I
love that point. The data center is the
new computer. I think that's a really
succinct way to put it. Maybe final
question for you personally about you as
a founder. I think you've climbed five
of the seven summits. One of your
company values is think like a
mountaineer. How have you and you've had
this company that has gone through many
different formulations of you and what
you're doing and constantly iterating.
How how has your company culture
influenced getting you here?
Uh yeah, I mean you know that value to
think like a mountaineer was was kind of
a special one and very unique to Crusoe.
Um and you know it sort of came out of
the fact that you know I had actually
just come back from climbing Mount
Everest when when I when I founded Cruso
and it was kind of like you know I had
mountaineering on my mind quite a bit.
Um and uh you know I was thinking about
a lot of these practices of being a
successful mountaineer and how they
would actually inform being a good
employee at a company and uh uh you know
in our case it was like look I don't
want everybody to be an extreme athlete
that like goes and has to go climb
mountains to be a good employee. Uh but
I want them to channel some of those
same thoughts and and practices that
really make those those things
successful. So, you know, when you're
climbing in the mountains, uh, you have
to you have to you have to have a plan
A, like you know, you have a plan to get
to the top and, you know, hopefully the
the weather holds up and, you know,
everything goes to plan, but you also
have to plan for things to go wrong. And
I think that resilience and robustness
really embedded into every aspect of uh
our process designs and and um uh our
organization designs has really led to
being able to thrive amidst multiple
different chaotic periods, you know, um
throughout throughout the company's
history. So, uh, you know, resilience
and chaos, I think, is like a a great,
um, you know, principle that we've, uh,
uh, been able to, uh, do well with.
Thank you. Thanks so much, David.
